llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: GraphQL Introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response contains an active introspection result: the \"__schema\" object and a comprehensive \"types\" list (including __Type and __Schema). This indicates the server allows GraphQL introspection queries and is disclosing the schema and available types/fields. Exposing the schema in production can facilitate attacker reconnaissance (discovering queries, types, field names, and potential sensitive fields/endpoints) and make it easier to craft targeted attacks or exploit business-logic flaws. Recommendation: disable or restrict introspection in production (or require authentication/authorization), enforce schema/query whitelisting, and apply rate limiting and monitoring to reduce the risk from automated enumeration.", "evidence": "\"__schema\": { \"types\": [ ... ] }\" present in the response body (includes __Type, __Schema and a full list of types and fields)", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "GraphQL Introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "\"__schema\": { \"types\": [ ... ] }\" present in the response body (includes __Type, __Schema and a full list of types and fields)", "explanation": "The GraphQL response contains an active introspection result: the \"__schema\" object and a comprehensive \"types\" list (including __Type and __Schema). This indicates the server allows GraphQL introspection queries and is disclosing the schema and available types/fields. Exposing the schema in production can facilitate attacker reconnaissance (discovering queries, types, field names, and potential sensitive fields/endpoints) and make it easier to craft targeted attacks or exploit business-logic flaws.
